text: with [url=https://github.com/aiekick/NoodlesPlate/releases]Noodlesplate[/url] you can import your sahder from shadertoy and then use the timeline for manipulate uniforms (you cand efine your owns). by ex deifne the iTime at frame 0 and frame 90. and then export all pictures from timeline menu. then you can assemble the pictures to a video with tool like blender 3d :)
@Dave_Hoskins thanks! I have not heard of it before, but based on your renders it look very promising!

@s23b Have you tried SynthClipse? It's a Java (off-line, not JS) based tool I use to export my Shadertoy films, it's directly compatible with Shadertoy locations and supports the uniforms & buffers. You can also render multiple resolution sizes for anti-aliasing:
http://synthclipse.sourceforge.net/
Ok, I will think about it !
@ttoinou the ones I found are all browser-based, and had the same crashing issues you mentioned.
Nice one!
Maybe ! I have to think about it ! Arent there already a few github repo about that ? Will add the tag to my others clips

Good idea. I added the the tag.

Are you planing to release your program? Sounds like a great tool that a lot of us would use :)

You made a real videoclip timed to the music here ! If you discover others like this one on shadertoy send it to me to be generated for YouTube ! We should have a tag for this. What about "musicclip" ?

Hi ! You're welcome. I had to edit the background blueprint lines to make it in 8K, and also the diagonal gradient lines

3 years ago I used to use a Chrome extension that rendered 6K frames out of Chrome (8K was crashing) but now I have my own external OpenGL program on Windows that outputs the frames I want in non realtime :)   

Next step, testing VR360 and testing HDR on YouTube

@ttoinou thanks, this is great! I have never seen it run this smoothly outside of the low-res editing view :)

I'm curious, how did you render this?

yep, working.

I'm on chrome & firefox / linux / Nvidia Quadro K2100M

note that on windows, you can be either on Angle (i.e. DirectX9 or 11 via transpiling) or Native OpenGL, and it often give very different results.

thanks Fabrice! :) I added this modification, it should work now.
out of curiosity, what os/browser/gpu combo did you observe this on?

already tried: it locks to white.  but if I replace PI / 2. by PI / 2. -1e-5,
seems there is something wrong with rot.y = PI/2 exactly.

weird... I want to get to the bottom of this. What if you change it to this?
mix(sin(iGlobalTime * SPEED) * PI / 8., PI / 2., 1.));
then it's ok !

and what if you replace line 293 with this?
mix(sin(iGlobalTime * SPEED) * PI / 8., PI / 2., 0.));
no change.
maybe it has to do with Buf A... is it better now?

indeed it's totally white the 10 first seconds.
If I move the mouse there is the 3D graph but back to white if I release.
Then after 10" it's ok.
@Fabrice strange, the issue doesn't happen on my end... I tweaked line 286 now. Is it better?
